column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Think Coherently

#Text=Thinking affects every aspect of life ; however , you usually want to think especially well when you are engaging in a few common activities : speaking , listening , writing , reading , deciding , or persuading .
#Text=Thinking well helps you decide when others ' opinions have merit , and you persuade others to see when your opinion has merit .
#Text=For many people grappling with ideas in those situations , thoughts can become jumbled .
#Text=If you are grappling with complexity , there is an easy place to start thinking well .
#Text=The following suggestions can often help you identify and engage with coherent opinions .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Start with the basics .
#Text=You would be surprised at how many think that the following suggestions are so basic that they do not engage with them systematically .
#Text=As a consequence , people often do not know what to think , what their own opinions are .
#Text=List the ideas that you think are relevant to the situation , motivation , or topic .
#Text=If you are reading an expert opinion , does she cover what you think is relevant ?
#Text=If you are writing your opinion , do you cover what others will find relevant ? ( 2 ) Among the relevant ideas , which are the most important ?
#Text=The few important ideas will cause the merely relevant ideas to adapt their meanings to the situation in perhaps unique ways .
#Text=Can you identify which ideas others find important when they are talking to you ?

#Text=Can you communicate which ideas you think are important when you are talking to them ? ( 3 ) Once you have established a cognitive foundation of relevance and importance , you are in a position to tackle what most people think is the foundation of critical and coherent thinking : is the opinion you are listening to or enunciating true ?
#Text=Sort them .
#Text=Truth is easier to hear and say if you first know which ideas are relevant and which of those ideas are the most important .
#Text=How will you know which ideas are relevant and important ?
#Text=Well , that is sort of a mystery , but your mind has been learning how to do that your whole life .
#Text=You are so good at determining relevance and importance , that it has become subconscious .
#Text=Trust those feelings .
#Text=Allow them to the be foundation of what you think .
#Text=Work out what to say in advance .
#Text=Thinking coherently is begun by forming what you need to say within your head , as a general rule of thumb .
#Text=It is often said that thinking is like talking to yourself internally .
#Text=The idea is to make this dialogue understandable to yourself so that you are very aware of what is going on internally .
#Text=Make sure that the words you use are adequate for the purpose they mean to serve .
#Text=Use words that are accurate descriptors of the thing being thought , in order to gain greater accuracy in your depictions of that thing and in the sentences you formulate .
#Text=Make sure that what you are saying internally is clear .
#Text=Be aware of any confusion .
#Text=Expand your vocabulary by reading and listening to people talk .
#Text=This will help you to have the words you require to formulate streams of thought inside your head .
#Text=Look at where you are struggling to think .
#Text=Consider what you are struggling to think about .
#Text=Then , try to find ways to think about it using either more descriptors or better defining what you already know .
